newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: TAIWAN FACTORIES STAGE ONE-DAY PROTESTS IN SAFRICA.
newsitem.headline: TAIWAN FACTORIES STAGE ONE-DAY PROTESTS IN SAFRICA.

text.p: Taiwanese factories in South Africa plan to close for a series of one-day stoppages starting on Thursday to protest Pretoria's decision to cut ties with Taiwan in favour of Beijing.

Chairman of the Association of Chinese Industrialists in Southern Africa, William Wang, told Reuters the rolling protests would end on Tuesday and would affect about 35,000 workers in 280 factories with a total investment of 4.3 billion rand.
"We want to pass on the message to the South African government that we are very, very dissappointed with the cutting of ties with Taiwan," Wang said.
Wang said he hoped the South African government would honour its pledge to maintain the highest level of relations with Taiwan after formal diplomatic ties are severed.
South Africa, the biggest of Taiwan's only 30 diplomatic allies, announced in late 1996 that it would switch recognition to Beijing from Taipei by the end of 1997.
